genotypes were analysed based on the genetic
model of proposed risk (rapid and intermediate acetylation
polymorphisms. All of the statistical analyses were per-
formed using STATA version 14.2 (Stata, College Station,
TX, USA) and SPSS version 16.0 (SPSS, USA). Based on com-
controls, the pooled ORs and their 95% con
(CIs) were calculated and displayed as forest plots to assess
phisms and susceptibility to AT-DILI in TB patients. In this
analysis, pre-stated ethnic subgroup analyses were per-
formed to examine differences in the association between
genotype distribution and AT-DILI risk. Subgroup
analyses were performed by: (i) region of origin (East Asia,
South Asia, Southeast Asia, West Asia, Africa, Europe, South
HRM, RFLP, Taqman, SNP stream). Random effects or
effects models were used depending on the heterogeneity
among studies. Heterogeneity was assessed using the stan-
idence of heterogeneity. Among all quali
gene, we drew up the summary effects again after re-
moving the study with the widest 95% con
(CI). We also conducted a sensitivity analysis to assess the
stability of the results by applying the leave-one-out method,
that is repeating the meta-analysis, each time omitting one
of the studies. Publication bias was assessed using Begg
Using our electronic database searches, we identi
articles describing the strength of the postulated genetic
bility to AT-DILI. A total of 37 case
cohort design studies with 1527 AT-DILI cases and 7184
controls without AT-DILI were included in the meta-analysis.

Secondly, a subgroup analysis was performed across study
designs (Figure 4). Of the 37 studies, 19 were case
studies, and one was a retrospective cohort study. The sub-
groups all showed positive effects sizes, ranging from 1.90
Subgroup analysis for different methods of genotyping
was performed (Figure 5). Of the 37 studies, 15 used se-
quencing, 18 used RFLP, two used Taqman, one used
HRM, one used SNP stream. The subgroups all showed
positive effects sizes, ranging from 2.06 (95% CI 0.93

The sensitivity analysis was conducted via sequential analysis
after omitting one study at a time to assess the effects of indi-
vidual studies on the overall meta-analysis estimate. This
analysis shows that the results of the meta-analysis are statis-
